00017 =head1 NAME
00018 
00019 parserAssignment.pl - Implements assignments to variables
00020 
00021 =head1 DESCRIPTION
00022 
00023 This file implements an assignment operator that allows only a single
00024 variable reference on the left and any value on the right.  You can use
00025 this to require students to enter things like
00026 
00027     y = 3x + 1
00028 
00029 rather than making the "y = " part of the text of the question.  This
00030 also allows you to ask for lists of assignments more easily.
00031 
00032 To use it, load the macro file, select the Context you want to use,
00033 add any variables you may need, and enable the assignment operator as
00034 in the following example:
00035 
00036     loadMacros(
00037       "PGstandard.pl",
00038       "MathObjects.pl",
00039       "parserAssignment.pl",
00040     );
00041 
00042     Context("Numeric")->variables->add(y=>'Real');
00043     parser::Assignment->Allow;
00044 
00045 Now you can use the equal sign in Formula() objects to create assignments.
00046 
00047     $f = Formula("y = 3x + 1");
00048     ...
00049     ANS($f->cmp);
00050 
00051 The student will have to make an assignment to the same variable in
00052 order to get credit.  For example, he or she could enter y = 1+3x to get
00053 credit for the answer above.
00054 
00055 The left-hand side of an assignment must be a single variable, so
00056 
00057     $f = Formula("3y = 2x");
00058 
00059 will produce an error.  The right-hand side can not include the
00060 variable being assigned on the left, so
00061 
00062     $f = Formula("x = 2x+1");
00063 
00064 also is not allowed.
00065 
00066 You can produce lists of assignments just as easily:
00067 
00068     $f = Formula("y = 3x, y = 2x-1");
00069 
00070 and the assignment can be of any type of MathObject.  For example:
00071 
00072     Context("Vector")->variables->add(p=>'Vector3D');
00073     parser::Assignment->Allow;
00074 
00075     $f = Formula("p = <1,2x,1-x>");
00076 
00077 To produce a constant assignment, use Compute(), as in:
00078 
00079     $p = Compute("p = <1,2,3>");
00080 
00081 (in fact, Compute() could be used for in place of Formula() in the
00082 examples above as well, since it returns a Formula when the value is
00083 one).
00084 
00085 The left-hand side of an assignment can also be a function
00086 declaration, as in
00087 
00088     f(x) = 3x + 1
00089 
00090 To allow this, use
00091 
00092     parser::Assignment->Function("f");
00093 
00094 You can supply more than one function name if you want.  E.g.,
00095 
00096     parser::Assignment->Function("f","g");
00097 
00098 The number of variables for these functions is determined by the
00099 assignment itself, so after declaring f to be a function, you can use
00100 either
00101 
00102     f(x) = x+1
00103 or
00104     f(x,y) = x^2 + y^2
00105 
00106 provided the variables are defined in the current context.
00107 
00108 Type-checking between the student and correct answers is performed
00109 using the right-hand values of the assignment, and a warning message
00110 will be issued if the types are not compatible.  The type of the
00111 variable on the left-hand side, however, is not checked.
00112 
00113 For function declarations, the name of the function and the order
00114 of the variables must match the professor's answer; however, the
00115 names of the variables don't have to match, as long as the function
00116 returns the same results for the same inputs.  So
00117 
00118     f(x) = x + 1
00119 and
00120     f(y) = y + 1
00121 
00122 will be marked as equal.
00123 
00124 =cut
00125 
00126 #
00127 #  FIXME:  allow any variables in declaration
00128 #  FIXME:  Add more hints when variable name isn't right
00129 #          or function name or number of arguments isn't right.
00130 #
00131 
00132 sub _parserAssignment_init {parser::Assignment::Init()}

00134 ######################################################################
00135 
00136 package parser::Assignment;
00137 our @ISA = qw(Parser::BOP);
00138 
00139 sub Init {
00140   main::PG_restricted_eval('sub Assignment {parser::Assignment::List->new(@_)}');
00141 }
00142 
00143 #
00144 #  Check that the left operand is a variable and not used on the right
00145 #
00146 sub _check {
00147   my $self = shift; my $name = $self->{def}{string} || $self->{bop};
00148   $self->Error("Only one assignment is allowed in an equation")
00149     if $self->{lop}->type eq 'Assignment' || $self->{rop}->type eq 'Assignment';
00150   $self->Error("The left side of an assignment must be a variable or function",$name)
00151     unless $self->{lop}->class eq 'Variable' || $self->{lop}{isDummy} || $self->context->flag("allowBadOperands");
00152   if ($self->{lop}{isDummy}) {
00153     my $fvars = $self->{lop}->getVariables;
00154     foreach my $x (keys(%{$self->{rop}->getVariables})) {
00155       $self->Error("The formula for %s can't use the variable '%s'",$self->{lop}->string,$x)
00156     unless $fvars->{$x};
00157     }
00158   } else {
00159     $self->Error("The right side of an assignment must not include the variable being defined")
00160       if $self->{rop}->getVariables->{$self->{lop}{name}};
00161     delete $self->{equation}{variables}{$self->{lop}{name}};
00162   }
00163   $self->{type} = Value::Type('Assignment',2,$self->{rop}->typeRef,list => 1);
00164 }
00165 
00166 #
00167 #  Convert to an Assignment object
00168 #
00169 sub eval {
00170   my $self = shift; my $context = $self->context;
00171   my ($a,$b) = ($self->Package("String")->make($context,$self->{lop}->string),$self->{rop});
00172   $b = Value::makeValue($b->eval,context => $context);
00173   return parser::Assignment::List->make($context,$a,$b);
00174 }
00175 
00176 #
00177 #  Don't count the left-hand variable
00178 #
00179 sub getVariables {
00180   my $self = shift;
00181   return $self->{lop}->getVariables if $self->{lop}{isDummy};
00182   $self->{rop}->getVariables;
00183 }
00184 
00185 #
00186 #  Create an Assignment object
00187 #
00188 sub perl {
00189   my $self = shift;
00190   return "parser::Assignment::List->new('".$self->{lop}->string."',".$self->{rop}->perl.")";
00191 }
00192 
00193 #
00194 #  Add/Remove the Assignment operator to/from a context
00195 #
00196 sub Allow {
00197   my $self = shift || "Value"; my $context = shift || $self->context;
00198   my $allow = shift; $allow = 1 unless defined($allow);
00199   if ($allow) {
00200     my $prec = $context->{operators}{','}{precedence};
00201     $prec = 1 unless defined($prec);
00202     $context->operators->add(
00203       '=' => {
00204          class => 'parser::Assignment',
00205          precedence => $prec+.25,  #  just above comma
00206          associativity => 'left',  #  computed left to right
00207          type => 'bin',            #  binary operator
00208          string => ' = ',          #  output string for it
00209       }
00210     );
00211     $context->{value}{Formula} = 'parser::Assignment::Formula';
00212     $context->{value}{Assignment} = 'parser::Assignment::List';
00213   } else {$context->operators->remove('=')}
00214   return;
00215 }
00216 
00217 sub Function {
00218   my $self = shift || "Value";
00219   my $context = (Value::isContext($_[0]) ? shift : $self->context);
00220   Value->Error("You must provide a function name") unless scalar(@_) > 0;
00221   foreach my $f (@_) {
00222     Value->Error("Function name '%s' is illegal",$f) unless $f =~ m/^[a-z][a-z0-9]*$/i;
00223     my $name = $f; $name = $1.'_{'.$2.'}' if ($name =~ m/^(\D+)(\d+)$/);
00224     $context->functions->add(
00225       $f => {class => 'parser::Assignment::Function', TeX => $name, type => $Value::Type{number}}
00226     );
00227   }
00228 }

00230 ######################################################################
00231 
00232 #
00233 #  A special List object that holds a variable and a value, and
00234 #  that prints with an equal sign.
00235 #
00236 
00237 package parser::Assignment::List;
00238 our @ISA = ("Value::List");
00239 
00240 sub new {
00241   my $self = shift; my $class = ref($self) || $self;
00242   my $context = (Value::isContext($_[0]) ? shift : $self->context);
00243   Value->Error("Too many arguments") if scalar(@_) > 2;
00244   my ($x,$v) = @_;
00245   if (defined($v)) {
00246     my $context = $self->context;
00247     $v = Value::makeValue($v,context=>$context);
00248     if ($v->isFormula) {
00249       $x = $self->Package("Formula")->new($context,$x);
00250       $v->{tree} = parser::Assignment->new($v,"=",$x->{tree},$v->{tree});
00251       bless $v, $self->Package("Formula");
00252       return $v;
00253     }
00254     return $self->make($self->Package("String")->make($context,$x),$v);
00255   } else {
00256     $v = $self->Package("Formula")->new($x);
00257     Value->Error("Your formula doesn't seem to be an assignment")
00258     unless $v->{tree}->type eq "Assignment";
00259     return $v;
00260   }
00261 }
00262 
00263 sub string {
00264   my $self = shift; my ($x,$v) = $self->value;
00265   $x->string . ' = ' . $v->string;
00266 }
00267 
00268 sub TeX {
00269   my $self = shift; my ($x,$v) = $self->value;
00270   $x = $self->Package("Formula")->new($x->{data}[0]);
00271   $x->TeX . ' = ' . $v->string;
00272 }

00274 #
00275 #  Needed since these are called explicitly without an object
00276 #
00277 sub cmp_defaults {
00278   my $self = shift;
00279   $self->SUPER::cmp_defaults(@_);
00280 }
00281 
00282 #
00283 #  Class is an a variable assigned to whatever
00284 #
00285 sub cmp_class {
00286   my $self = shift;
00287   my $type = ($self->{data}[0] =~ m/\(/ ? 'Function' : 'Variable');
00288   "a $type equal to ".$self->{data}[1]->showClass;
00289 }
00290 sub showClass {cmp_class(@_)}
00291 
00292 #
00293 #  Return the proper type
00294 #
00295 sub typeRef {
00296   my $self = shift;
00297   Value::Type('Assignment',2,$self->{data}[1]->typeRef,list=>1);
00298 }

00300 ######################################################################
00301 
00302 #
00303 #  A subclass of Formula that does typematching properly for Assignments
00304 #  (the match is against the right-hand sides)
00305 #
00306 
00307 package parser::Assignment::Formula;
00308 our @ISA = ("Value::Formula");
00309 
00310 sub new {
00311   my $self = shift; $class = ref($self) || $self;
00312   my $f = $self->SUPER::new(@_);
00313   bless $f, $class if $f->type eq 'Assignment';
00314   return $f;
00315 }
00316 
00317 sub typeMatch {
00318   my $self = shift; my $other = shift; my $ans = shift;
00319   return 0 unless $self->type eq $other->type;
00320   $other = $other->Package("Formula")->new($self->context,$other) unless $other->isFormula;
00321   my $typeMatch = ($self->createRandomPoints(1))[1]->[0]{data}[1];
00322   $main::__other__ = sub {($other->createRandomPoints(1))[1]->[0]{data}[1]};
00323   $other = main::PG_restricted_eval('&$__other__()');
00324   delete $main::{__other__};
00325   return 1 unless defined($other); # can't really tell, so don't report type mismatch
00326   $typeMatch->typeMatch($other,$ans);
00327 }
00328 
00329 sub cmp_class {
00330   my $self = shift; my $value;
00331   if ($self->{tree}{rop}{isConstant}) {
00332     $value = ($self->createRandomPoints(1))[1]->[0]{data}[1];
00333   } else {
00334     $value = $self->Package("Formula")->new($self->context,$self->{tree}{rop});
00335   }
00336   my $type = ($self->{tree}{lop}{isDummy} ? "Function" : "Variable");
00337   return "a $type equal to ".$value->showClass;
00338 }
00339 sub showClass {cmp_class(@_)}
00340 
00341 #
00342 #  Convert varaible names to those used in the correct answer, if the
00343 #  student answer uses different ones
00344 #
00345 sub compare {
00346   my ($l,$r) = @_; my $self = $l;
00347   my $context = $self->context;
00348   $r = $context->Package("Formula")->new($context,$r) unless Value::isFormula($r);
00349   if ($l->{tree}{lop}{isDummy} && $r->type eq 'Assignment' && $r->{tree}{lop}{isDummy}) {
00350     my ($F,$f) = ($l->{tree}{lop}{params},$r->{tree}{lop}{params});
00351     if (scalar(@{$F}) == scalar(@{$f})) {
00352       my @subs = ();
00353       for (my $i = 0; $i < scalar(@{$F}); $i++) {
00354     push(@subs,$f->[$i]{name} => $F->[$i]{name})
00355       unless $F->[$i]{name} eq $f->[$i]{name};
00356       }
00357       $r = $r->substitute(@subs) if scalar(@subs);
00358       delete $r->{f};
00359     }
00360   }
00361   $l->SUPER::compare($r,@_);
00362 }
00363 
00364 ######################################################################
00365 
00366 #
00367 #  A dummy function that is used for assignments like f(x) = x^2
00368 #
00369 
00370 package parser::Assignment::Function;
00371 our @ISA = ("Parser::Function");
00372 
00373 sub _check {
00374   my $self = shift; my %var;
00375   foreach my $x (@{$self->{params}}) {
00376     $self->Error("The arguments of '%s' must be variables",$self->{name})
00377       unless $x->class eq 'Variable';
00378     $self->Error("The arguments of '%s' must all be different",$self->{name})
00379       if $var{$x->{name}};
00380     $var{$x->{name}} = 1;
00381   }
00382   $self->{type} = $self->{def}{type};
00383   $self->{isDummy} = 1;
00384 }
00385 
00386 sub eval {
00387   my $self = shift;
00388   $self->Error("Dummy function '%s' can not be evaluated",$self->{name});
00389 }
00390 
00391 sub call {
00392   my $self = shift;
00393   $self->Error("Dummy function '%s' can not be called",$self->{name});
00394 }
